Award.AwardTitle: The Art of Measuring Physical Parameters in Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF support is provided for a workshop on "The Art of Measuring Physical Parameters in Galaxies" to be held during April 10-13th 2018 at the Palm Desert conference center of the University of California, Riverside. This workshop builds upon and extends the successful Cosmic Assembly Near-infrared Deep Extragalactic Legacy Survey (CANDELS) project. The award will help support attendance of 20 younger astronomers and members of the minority groups.

There is now an extensive photometric and spectroscopic dataset available for CANDELS galaxies, driving a need to measure their associated physical parameters. The aim of the workshop is to bring together leaders in the field to discuss and identify the optimum ways to measure these parameters using the combined data from X-ray to radio wavelengths, to discuss the state-of-the-art science, and to identify the outstanding and fundamental projects that are only possible by exploiting such data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop was held in April 2019 at the University of California, Riverside. Specific Objectives of this workshop were:

1. To bring together young astronomers working on measuring the physical parameters in galaxies and providing the opportunities for them to collaborate. 

2. To finalize CANDELS project data catalogs containing all the physical parameters.  

3. To connect members of the minority groups and generate a network.

4. To produce a paper comparing different codes measuring physical parameters in galaxies and discuss advantages and disadvantages of each code.

All these objectives were met. We followed a new format for this workshop. After presentations by the attendees, the afternoon sessions were spent on training the researchers (specially those in the beginning of their career) in using different algorithms available for measuring the physical parameters in galaxies. After the meeting, the attendees became familiar with the pros and cons of different techniques used to measure these parameters. The result of this was a paper that compares different techniques and is now being ready for submission to the Astrophysical Journal (Pacifici et al ApJ 2019). Over 50 people participated in the workshop with 70% of them in the begining of their career. The meeting was so successful that a follow up meeting is now planned under the same title "The Art of Measuring Physical Parameters in Galaxies" in November 2019 in Milano, Italy. 

The workshop brought up new discussions and ideas as how to build CANDELS catalogs. The members of the team have been working on this eversince the meeting. We now have the final CANDELS catalogs with all the physical parameters estimated and ready for performing science. A number of studies are currently under progress to use these catalogs to do science (Chartab-Soltani et al 2019; Iyer et al 2019; Salmon et al 2019; Shahidi et al 2019). The workshop helped to organize the attempt to finalize the CANDELS catalogs and to perform final measurement of the physical parameters for individual galaxies in the CANDELS.  

Through this meeting, a new generation of astronomers were introduced to the CANDELS data, collaborations were started among them and plans were worked out to perform spectroscopic studies of the CANDELS galaxies. These investigations continued after the 2018 meeting and will be reviewed in our next meeting in November 2019. The meeting started a series of activities that include data processing and catalog generation, science discussions and papers and planning for follow-up observations.
